content.question: ​A balanced coin with one side heads (<math alttext="H"><mi>H</mi></math>) and the other side tails (<math alttext="T"><mi>T</mi></math>) is repeatedly flipped, and the results are recorded. The coefficients in the expansion of <math alttext="open parentheses H plus T close parentheses to the power of n"><msup><mfenced><mrow><mi>H</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>T</mi></mrow></mfenced><mi>n</mi></msup></math> give the number of ways to get a particular combination of heads and tails for <math alttext="n"><mi>n</mi></math> flips of the coin. For example, in the expansion of <math alttext="open parentheses H plus T close parentheses to the power of 7"><msup><mfenced><mrow><mi>H</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>T</mi></mrow></mfenced><mn>7</mn></msup></math>, the term <math alttext="21 H squared T to the power of 5"><mn>21</mn><msup><mi>H</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><msup><mi>T</mi><mn>5</mn></msup></math> means there are <math alttext="21"><mn>21</mn></math> ways to get exactly <math alttext="2"><mn>2</mn></math> heads and <math alttext="5"><mn>5</mn></math> tails when flipping a coin <math alttext="7"><mn>7</mn></math> times. How many ways are there to get exactly <math alttext="2"><mn>2</mn></math> heads and <math alttext="4"><mn>4</mn></math> tails when flipping a balanced coin <math alttext="6"><mn>6</mn></math> times?
